#Text=Measure Square Footage
#Text=Knowing how to measure square footage can be very useful for real estate rental and sale purposes , and it can also help you ace your next geometry test .

#Text=To measure the square footage of a space , separate the space into manageable parts , find the square footage of all those different parts ( usually by multiplying length times width ) , and add the square footage of all separate parts together to find the square footage of the overall space .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Find the Square Footage of a Space
#Text=Break down the area into manageable parts .
#Text=If you 're having trouble finding the square footage , then it 's probably because you 're not working with a neat area with just one length and one width .
#Text=The space might have squares jutting off in different places and could be shaped erratically .
#Text=All you have to do is split up the space into even squares or rectangles .
#Text=To find the square footage , or the area , of the entire space , you 'll need to find the square footage of the individual spaces and then add them all together .
#Text=Draw faint lines separating the different sections .
#Text=Label them A , B , and C for your convenience .
#Text=Measure the length and width of the first space .
#Text=Using a ruler or measuring tape , find the length and width of the first space you 've created , Space A.
#Text=The length of the space is , and the width is .
#Text=Multiply the length of the first space by the width of the first space .
#Text=To find the square footage -- or the area -- of the space , just multiply the length times the width , just as you would do with any rectangle .
#Text=Ex : . x . = 180 square feet
#Text=Measure the length and width of the second space .
#Text=Let 's say that the length of Space B is and the width of Space B is .
#Text=Multiply the length of the second space times the width of the second space .
#Text=This will lead you to find the square footage of the second space .
#Text=Here 's how you find the square footage of Space B :
#Text=Ex : . x . = 200 square feet .
#Text=Measure the length and width of the third space .
#Text=Let 's say that the length of Space C is and the width of Space C is .
#Text=Multiply the length of the third space times the width of the third space .
#Text=This will lead you to find the square footage of the third space .
#Text=Here 's how you find the square footage of Space C :
#Text=Ex : . x . = 700 square feet
#Text=Add the square footages of the three spaces .
#Text=Once you find the sum of the square footages of the three spaces , you 'll know the square footage of the entire space .
#Text=Here 's how you do it :
#Text=Square footage of Space A + square footage of Space B + square footage of Space C = square footage of the entire space
#Text=180 + 200 + 700 = 1080 square feet
#Text=Learn a Few Tricks for Finding Square Footage
#Text=Find the approximation of square footage .

#Text=If you 're looking for an approximation of square footage , you can also try measuring the outside of your home and then subtracting any areas that wo n't be factored in to the square footage , such as the porch stairs or garage .
#Text=Ceiling and floor tiles are often one square foot in size .
#Text=You can simply count these to get a close approximation of the total square footage .
#Text=Find the square footage of a space that 's shaped like a half-circle .

#Text=If there 's a part of your house that 's shaped like a half of a circle , you can find the square footage of the circle by finding the area of the space as if it were a full circle and then dividing it by half .
#Text=To do this , simply measure the long line that cuts the " circle " in half to get the diameter .
#Text=Next , divide that number by 2 to get the radius ( r ) and plug the result into the equation A = πr2 .
#Text=Finally , divide by 2 to get the area , or square footage , of the half circle .
#Text=Find the square footage of a space that 's almost regularly shaped .

#Text=If you 're measuring a space that is almost fully a square or a rectangle , with only a small square or rectangular part missing , then measure the square footage of the entire space as if the missing part was filled in .
#Text=Then , find the square footage of the missing part and subtract it from the overall square footage to find the square footage of the space .
#Text=This will save you time .
#Text=Quick Summary
